intro.description: Learn how to initialize a custom domain model and define it graphically. Sirius can work with any EMF-compatible domain model. You can use an existing standard like UML, or create you own Domain-Specific Model customized for you own needs. This cheat-sheet will show you how to use the Ecore modeler provided by Sirius to easily bootstrap the creation of your own domain model.

item.title: Setup
item.description: First, make sure you are in the "Sirius" perspective.

subitem.label: In the "Model Explorer" right, right-click and select "New > Ecore Modeling Project".
Enter the project name, like "com.example.project.domain". This will be the name of the main EMF plug-in which defines your domain model. Hit "Next".
In the next page, enter the namespace prefix and URI of the EMF package that will contain your domain definition. Then hit "Next".

In the next page you can choose which of the available viewpoints compatible with Ecore to enable. The "Design" viewpoint is enabled by default, and provide a class diagram-like graphical modeler for Ecore models. Hit "Finish".

item.title: Define your model
item.description:
The newly created project is both a complete EMF project (with the ecore and genmodel already created) and a Modeling project. If you have enabled the Design viewpoint, a diagram will automatically be opened, ready for you to define your domain model.
Refer to the Sirius Ecore Modeler documentation for how to use the modeler (in Help > Help Contents), and to the standard EMF Documentation on how to define your domain model and generate the corresponding Java code.
